frameDefinitions: These are words relating to filling containers and covering areas with some thing, things or substance, the Theme.
An Agent, Situation or Entity has an influence on a Cognizer.
The adjectives and nouns in this frame are all based on the idea that mental properties may be attributed to a person (Protagonist) by a (usually implicit)
A Speaker succeeds in getting an Addressee to believe or plan to execute the Content the Speaker has in mind.
In this frame an Abuser repeatedly treats the Victim in a cruel and violent way, including physically harming or forcing the Victim to engage in sexual activity against their will.
An Inspector attains a degree of certainty in the Unconfirmed_content, generally by inspecting some evidence.
frameExamples: Lionel Hutz <t>coated</t> the wall with paint.
These works had a profound effect and <t>influenced</t> her in the creation of a successful series capturing this sun-drenched region.
It was <t>stupid</t> of me to do that.
At one point, Walter tries to <t>convince</t> his wife that he has had a story accepted by BBC Radio.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Agent</fen> is the actor who instigates the filling.
The <fen>Theme</fen> is the physical object or substance which changes location.
The <fen>Goal</fen> is the area or container being filled. Goal is generally the NP Object in this frame.
An event which brings about the filling of the <fen>Goal</fen>.
When the filling occurs.
Where the filling takes place.
The person who is influenced by the <fen>Situation</fen> or <fen>Entity</fen>.
A state of affairs--- which can be an event, state or conditions---that has an influence on the <fen>Cognizer</fen>.
A person or thing that has an influence on the <fen>Cognizer</fen>.
An Action that the <fen>Cognizer</fen> decides to carry out as a consequence of the influence of a <fen>Situation</fen> or <fen>Entity</fen>.
A <fen>Behavior</fen> that the <fen>Cognizer</fen> is engaged in independently but whose execution is subsequently influenced by the <fen>Situation</fen> or <fen>Entity</fen>.
An entity that stands metonymically for the actions and considerations that produced it.
The <fen>Agent</fen> acts to influence a <fen>Cognizer</fen>.
The <fen>Time</fen> at which the Subjective_influencing event occurs.
The location in which one has influence.

This is the person (or people) to whom a mental property is attributed. The role may be expressed as External Argument of a predicative use of the adjective, as a PP Complement, or as the head noun modified by an attributive use of the adjective:

The <fen>Behavior</fen> refers to any action, utterance, belief, or artifact thereof on the basis of which a mental property is attributed to the <fen>Protagonist</fen>. The meaning of the English word <ment>behavior</ment> should not be taken to constrain the identity of this frame element too much---conceptually, this frame element includes things that would not normally be described using the word <ment>behavior</ment>.  Note the following examples:

Some of the words in this frame have a slightly different use in that they evaluate someone only with respect to their mental performance in some particular domain or capacity.  We call this domain or capacity <t>Practice</t>. E.g., She is <t>astute</t> <fex name='Practice'>at math</fex>. Note that this does not mean she is considered to be astute in general for doing math. Rather, she is astute with respect to math, but may be dumb with respect to other things. These uses probably belong in a different frame with words such as <ment>skilled</ment>, but for the time being they are marked with the role Practice. General Grammatical Observations:  The adjectives in this frame may exhibit Extraposition of a <ment>to</ment>-marked infinitive VP, with an optional Protagonist expressed in an <ment>of</ment>-PP: It was <t>brilliant</t> (of you) <fex name='Prac'>to invite the clowns to the party</fex>.
The person that the Speaker seeks to influence to act.
The person who intends through the use of language to get another person to act.
The wish for action on the <fen>Addressee</fen>'s part that the <fen>Speaker</fen> expresses.
A piece of written or spoken material that changes the mind of the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
The general item or items that are the focus of the <fen>Content</fen> of the <fen>Speaker</fen>'s message.
When the <fen>Speaker</fen> suades the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
The location where the Speaker suades the Addressee.
The <fen>Abuser</fen> subjects the <fen>Victim</fen> to repeated verbal, physical, emotional or sexual attacks.
The <fen>Victim</fen> is the recipient of the <fen>Abuser</fen>'s actions.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the abuse occurs.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the abuse occurs.
The individual or individuals that ascertain that the <fen>Unconfirmed_content</fen> is true.
An open proposition that the <fen>Inspector</fen> decides by examining evidence.  It is usually a propostion put forward which some parties would disbelieve or contest.
The <fen>Medium</fen> is the piece of text or work in which the <fen>Inspector</fen> verifies the <fen>Unconfirmed_content</fen>:
This role describes the <fen>Time</fen> at which the verification event takes place.
This role describes where the verificiation event takes place.
listRoleExamples: Rev. Lovejoy carefully brushed the rolls <fex>with butter</fex>.
George Gilder would run with this idea later in writing the New Testament of supply-side economics that influenced <fex>Reagan</fex>.
<fex>The balmy temperatures</fex> inspired me to write a poem on the advent of spring.
<fex>The painting</fex> inspired me to take a risk and use the intense green for the sky.
What factors influenced Nixon <fex>to issue the doctrine</fex>?
Attention will also be paid to St. Paul , what influenced him <fex>in his thinking</fex> and what he wrote in his letters about sex, sexuality, men and women
Does anyone know what inspired <fex>this song</fex>?
Chavez has much influence <fex>in South America</fex>.
<fex>You</fex> were smart to save all your receipts.
<fex>His speech</fex> convinced me to join the Peace Corps.
You haven't convinced me <fex>about that yet</fex>.
<fex>Fred</fex> abused Martha by locking her into a closet .
Fred abused <fex>Martha</fex> by locking her into a closet .
<fex>His</fex> later verification of the facts is certainly beyond reproach.
It is extremely difficult to confirm <fex>the absence of something</fex>.
<fex>Chapter four</fex> confirms the reader 's suspicions completely.
